I have my doubts that they will be able to human rate the BFS. That landing sequence isn't called suicide burn without a reason, if the engine doesn't fire at the exact second it's supposed to the people on board are toast. Well they could add a lot of margin so they descend slower than the maximum thrust of whatever number of engines they will be using for descend but still, if there's any major malfunction with the fuel system or the engines people will slam into the ground. You could argue that the Apollo missions would also have been fucked if some engine on their way back from the moon didn't fire - but this would lead to the death of 2 or 3 highly trained national heroes which knew the risk and not the death of a hundred tourists or settlers.

if the mechanized parts are strong enough to handle heating issues, variable geometry makes sense for any space plane. 1) b/c space is a vacuum & center of mass matters the most for control & no real lift or drag force is felt. 2) in upper atmosphere, the atmosphere isn't evenly distributed + a aircraft is accelerating to or decelerating in the hypersonic velocities. Wings do not provide a lot of lift at this level, but they are good for control if they are the right shape as smaller control surfaces do not generate force to significantly control the craft. Typical aircraft that have enough thrust to achieve extremely high altitudes will enter dead spins when they loose control & that will stall out their engines if they haven't already from poor air intake. (Like the F-4 phantom.) 3) in the lower atmosphere and at landing, lift is a big factor preventing stall outs & and variable geometry is managed by much smaller control surfaces. Despite having these control surfaces it's not common to think of these aircraft as "variable geometry" but technically, they kind of are.
4) A spacecraft making entry/exit into both Mars & Earth will have completely different optimized profiles based on the composition & depth of the atmospheres.

Variable geometry concludes the forces involved in flight at every stage & speed prevent a one-size fits-all mentality, and works around it by modifying the surface dimensions of the craft.

HOWEVER, the downfall of most variable geometry designs in aviation is the reason the f-14 got supplanted relatively early in its aviation career by the f-15 is reliability & cost. The more moving parts in the system, the more can go wrong & that added complexity also increases the costs of production & maintenance. Most aircraft today have fixed designs that are optimized for their mission profile. Birds & bats & all other flying creatures are by nature variable geometry.


The multi-payload, multirole, multi-altitude, multi-atmospheric capabilities that Elon Musk wants Space X to achieve in a single craft pretty much defaults to variable geometry (cuz physics) with the engineering challenge being reducing the costs & complexities of continued operation with such things because the f-14 and the concord, and many other craft, the costs of operation has been the killer of the program. (However, they were competing economically with completely reusable & reliably optimized aircraft already in the market & mass produced not all these one-build-one mission throwaway rocket programs that Space X has been trying to usurp.)

If we ever invent real airtight forcefields air & space craft can be whatever physical shape you want them to be, because the field could likely provide all the variable geometry required to create desired maneuvers. We would see one shape, while the air would react to the field shape.

Not a fan of the BFS taking on the form of a Space Shuttle, winged structures add weight that reduces payload.  Why not use panels that hinge out from the hull.  They would be curved but aerodynamic perfection is not needed for scrubbing off energy whilst maintaining stability. Once the velocity is low enough to engage engines these panels would close back up snug with the hull to minimise the ‘dart’ effect.

Iteration is king.

Please do not call flow separation in an over expanded nozzle "combustion instability".  Combustion instability occurs in the combustion chamber, not in the expansion nozzle, and is a different phenomena.  Virtually nothing in the exhaust flow in the expansion nozzle can effect the combustion chamber since the exhaust is going several times the speed of sound therefore pressure in the exhaust cannot travel against the flow into the combustion chamber.

My thoughts about the angular front end: This makes the satellite launcher configuration, with the hinged "mouth," more realistic, more sturdy, easier to engineer.

I imagine the continuous design process involves setting aside ideas that are too much of a change "for now," keep those ideas in mind as they work on other details until one of the alternate approaches seems to solve a large number of problems with the current approach. If the advantages hold as the new approach fleshes out they update the concept art and show off their progress. Maybe that's obvious, maybe it's wrong; I have trouble telling the difference sometimes.
